data:
Criteria for Major Burn Fluid Resuscitation:
-Patients 65 years of age or older with burns greater than or equal to 10% TBSA
-Patients younger than 65 years of age and with burns greater than or equal to 20% TBSA
For delayed resuscitations, use clinical judgement to calculate the initial IV rate and titrate according to urine output
See link for Resuscitation Fluid Calculation
See link for Adult Major Burn TBSA burn estimation chart
Major Burn Estimated 24 hour Fluid Goals
At the end of the 24 hour fluid resuscitation, contact provider for IV maintenance rate and urine output monitoring
q1h, special instructions: Urine output goal 30 to 50 mL/hour
For electrical burns. Injury is a result of direct contact with high voltage, NOT burns sustained from electrical arc (flash) without direct contact
q1h, special instructions: Urine output goal 50 to 100 mL/hour
Modify lactated ringers titratable infusion order to indicate starting rate
Titrate, IV, 0 mL/h minimum rate, 999 mL/h maximum rate, titrate instructions: As per comments, drug form: bag

RN to complete the 8 hour after injury re-assessment calculations: 
Multiply the 8 hour total fluids administered by 2, if the product is greater than the estimated 24 hour total IV fluids, contact provider
If/when: 8 hour after burn fluid resuscitation reassessment is greater than estimated 24 hour total fluids, then contact provider
If/when: 8 hour after burn fluid resuscitation reassessment is greater than estimated 24 hour total fluids, then assess for signs and symptoms of intra-abdominal hypertension
If/when: 8 hour after burn fluid resuscitation reassessment is greater than estimated 24 hour total fluids, then assess for signs of extremity compartment syndrome
